title: 108_hr4649
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Discretionary Spending Control Act of 2004" and includes an extension of discretionary spending limits. The "Discretionary Spending Control Act of 2004" amends spending limits for fiscal year 2004, reducing amounts in various categories. New budget authority and outlays are specified for the general purpose discretionary category for the following year. The "Discretionary Spending Control Act of 2004" adjusts spending limits for fiscal year 2004, with specific allocations for the general purpose discretionary category, highway category, and mass transit category for the next year. In fiscal years 2007 and 2008, there are specific allocations for the highway and mass transit categories, with designated amounts for new budget authority and outlays. In fiscal years 2007 and 2008, specific allocations were made for the highway and mass transit categories, with designated amounts for new budget authority and outlays. For the mass transit category in fiscal year 2009, there is $2,017,000,000 in new budget authority and $8,968,000,000 in outlays. In fiscal years 2007 and 2008, specific allocations were made for highway and mass transit categories. For the mass transit category in fiscal year 2009, there is $2,017,000,000 in new budget authority and $8,968,000,000 in outlays. Amendments include new clauses for Motor Carrier Safety Grants and Operations and Programs. Amendments to transportation legislation include changes to funding categories and allocations for highway and mass transit. The amendments also update references to specific sections within the Transportation Equity Act. SEC. 3. ADJUSTMENTS TO ALIGN HIGHWAY SPENDING WITH REVENUES. SEC. 3. ADJUSTMENTS TO ALIGN HIGHWAY SPENDING WITH REVENUES. Subparagraphs (B) through (E) of section 251(b)(1) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 are amended to align highway spending with revenues. OMB will calculate adjustments based on actual highway receipts and estimated levels for the budget year and outyears. OMB will adjust highway obligations by adding half the sum of calculated amounts to the obligation limitations set forth in the Transportation Equity Act. This adjustment aligns highway spending with revenues. The estimated level of highway receipts for fiscal years 2004 to 2009 are as follows: $30,572,000,000; $34,260,000,000; $35,586,000,000; $36,570,000,000; $37,603,000,000; and $38,651,000,000. The term 'highway receipts' refers to governmental receipts credited to the Highway Trust Fund. In addition to adjustments required for the budget, an adjustment to the limits on outlays for highway and mass transit categories is calculated and included in the budget for fiscal years 2006 to 2009. The OMB and CBO will estimate outlays for categories in fiscal years 2005-2009 based on current assumptions. OMB will adjust these estimates when the President submits the budget for fiscal years 2006-2009. OMB will consult with the Committees on the Budget. OMB will consult with the Committees on the Budget and include a report on adjustments in the preview report. SEC. 4. LEVEL OF OBLIGATION LIMITATIONS. The obligation limitations for the highway category are as follows:
- 2004: $34,309,000,000
- 2005: $35,671,000,000
- 2006: $36,719,000,000
- 2007: $37,800,000,000
- 2008: $38,913,000,000
- 2009: $40,061,000,000

For the mass transit category:
- 2004: $7,266,000,000
- 2005: $7,750,000,000
- 2006: $8,266,000,000
- 2007: $8,816,000,000 For fiscal years 2007, 2008, and 2009, the obligation limitations for the mass transit category were $8,816,000,000, $9,403,000,000, and $10,029,000,000 respectively. The term "obligation limitations" refers to the sum of budget authority and obligation limitations. SEC. 5. ADVANCE APPROPRIATIONS. This section amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to include provisions for discretionary advance appropriations exceeding $23,558,000,000 in fiscal years 2005 through 2007. These appropriations will be counted against the discretionary spending limits for the respective fiscal year. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include definitions for advance appropriations and emergency requirements. Advance appropriations become available one fiscal year or more beyond the fiscal year of enactment. Emergency requirements provide new budget authority for urgent situations posing a threat to life, property, or national security. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include definitions for advance appropriations and emergency requirements. Emergency situations must be unforeseen, unpredictable, and temporary in nature to qualify for new budget authority. Fire suppression funding for fiscal years 2005 and 2006 is addressed in the amendment. The amendment addresses fire suppression funding for fiscal years 2005 and 2006, with a limit of $400,000,000 for the Forest Service and $100,000,000 for the Department of the Interior. The base amount is determined by the average obligations of the 10 preceding fiscal years. For wildfire suppression funding in the Forest Service and Department of the Interior, the base amount is determined by the average obligations of the 10 preceding fiscal years. For fiscal year 2005, the base amount is $880,000,000. Additionally, for contingency operations related to the global war on terrorism in fiscal year 2005, the adjustment shall be the total of supplemental appropriations in discretionary accounts designated by the President and Congress, not to exceed $50,000,000,000. In fiscal year 2005, the adjustment for contingency operations related to the global war on terrorism shall not exceed $50,000,000,000. The general purpose discretionary category consists of accounts designated in the joint explanatory statement of managers accompanying the conference report on the Spending Control Act of 2004. SEC. 7. PROJECTIONS UNDER SECTION 257.

Section 257(c) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to limit new budgetary resources designated under certain sections to the fiscal year they are enacted.

SEC. 8. REPORTS.

Certain sections of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 are amended to update the years for reporting purposes.

SEC. 9. EXPIRATION. SEC. 9. EXPIRATION.

Section 275(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to extend the expiration date to 2006 (or 2009 for enforcing spending limits on highways and mass transit).
